title: 'It's been brewing': Two years after epic seven-game ALCS, Astros and Yankees set for rematch
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: And then there were four. The Houston Astros clinched their ticket to the ALCS. Here's everything you need to know heading into the league championship series. USA TODAY

HOUSTON — Houston Astros manager A.J. Hinch thought the first time he heard it was when he arrived at spring training.

Justin Verlander, the Astros’ likely Cy Young winner, says he definitely remembers people talking about it on April 8, the first time the New York Yankees came to town.

Now that he thinks about it, Astros MVP candidate Alex Bregman says, he doesn’t remember a day this season when he didn’t hear about it.

The Houston Astros vs. the New York Yankees.

The Astros made sure it would happen Thursday, defeating the pesky Tampa Bay Rays, 6-1, and winning their American League Division Series, three games to two. The Yankees clinched their berth Monday with a three-game sweep over the Minnesota Twins.

Now, the marquee matchup begins Saturday night at Minute Maid Park in Houston.

Power hitting vs. Power pitching.

Super bullpen vs. Super starters.

And enough star power to light up the billboards on Broadway.

Jose Altuve crosses home plate after hitting a home run against the Yankees in April. (Photo: Thomas Shea, USA TODAY Sports)

“When you look at the two best teams in the American League, it’s been us and them all year," said Astros president Reid Ryan, son of Hall of Famer Nolan Ryan. “It’s only fitting we’re meeting up.

“You’re matching some of the game’s biggest stars. The power from the plate and the mound are going against each other. To be the best, you’ve got to beat the best, and look, they’re the best team in baseball, them and us, so I think it’s great we’re facing each other.’’

“It’s been brewing,’’ said Verlander, who will pitch Game 2 of the series with Zack Greinke scheduled to go Game 1 and Cole in Game 3. “We heard about it from the first series we played against each other. Here’s an ALCS preview.

“It worked out. These are two incredible powerhouse teams. We’ll find ourselves in the middle of the ring and we’ll be going at it.’’

Says Astros center fielder Jake Marisnick: We’re looking forward to it. They’re looking forward to it. It’s going to be a battle. We’ve been hearing the rumblings of this since spring training, and now it’s here.

“We’re going to go toe-to-toe with them.’’

There’s no need for ring announcer Michael Buffer.

“I heard it from Day 1,’’’ Hinch says, “just the way the teams are aligned. And the moves that were made in the off-season to set up teams. We both went through a lot of injuries, but it never really stopped either of us with the depth we had. And now we delivered to have one of the premier matchups to see who represents the American League in the World Series.’’

The Astros have a chance to be known as the greatest team of this decade.

The Yankees have a chance to end their 10-year World Series drought, and assure that this won’t be the first decade in franchise history without a World Series appearance.

“We understand what’s at stake,’’ Hinch says. “We don’t scare off. And now we have one of the toughest teams in the major leagues to have to get to the World Series.

“So buckle up.’’

If there’s an edge, the Astros believe, they have it simply because they have home-field advantage. They don’t have to jump on a plane Friday morning for New York. The Yankees have to come to them.

Besides, the Astros still remember back to two years ago when the home team won every game.

“It feels important, even more important today,’’ Hinch says. “Everybody talks about Game 6 and 7 at the end of the [2017] series. I like the fact that the series is opening up here because we need a partial day off. I'm exhausted after this series.’’

Besides, the Astros believe they have a huge advantage with their quirky ballpark. They know all of the nooks and crannies at Minute Maid Park from the Crawford Boxes in left field to the high rafters with the roof closed.

There’s a reason the Astros set a franchise record by going 60-21 at home, winning 32 of their last 40 and became the first team to win 60 home games since the 1998 Yankees.

“It’s a little bit of a different ballpark,’’ Verlander said. “It’s a different aesthetic for visiting teams. The crowd is incredible in the playoffs. And we’re comfortable here. It’s like Yankee Stadium, they’re comfortable there.

“Home field advantage is one of those funny things that you can’t really quantify, but it truly exists. We are extremely confident in any ballpark, but when we come home, man, it’s game on.’’

Nolan Ryan, the great Hall of Fame pitcher himself, is almost always sitting in the front row.

“[Owner] Jim Crane says, “I’m going to put your dad front row every time Verlander rand Cole pitches,’’ Reid Ryan said, “because they tend to pitch better when they know Nolan was watching.’ There is no bigger fan of those guys than my dad.

“To have he and Verlander on the same staff – and throw Greinke in there – the type of excellence we’re able to watch on a nightly basis is incredible.’’

So, go ahead, grab yourself a seat.

“They’ve got a really good team,’’ says Bregman, whose mother grew up in New York City and was a Yankee fan growing up, “and we’ve got a really good team. I think throughout the year both of us thought we’d have to play each other in the postseason. It’s going to be a lot of fun.’’

The Astros are trying to win their second World Series championship in three years and believe this team one of the best of all time. Yet, the only way they’ll be remembered, Bregman says, is to win the World Series.

“We know we have a chance to do something special,’’ Bregman says. “We won a lot of games. We have All-Stars at every position. But there’s one thing left to do, and that’s to win [the World Series].’’
description: Two years after the Astros came out ahead in seven games, the Yankees will get another shot at getting bat to the World Series.
